Award.AwardTitle: UPDATE: Utilities Pipeline Development for Advanced Technological Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Utilities Pipeline Development for Advanced Technological Education (UPDATE) project at Northeast Wisconsin Technical College addresses critical issues in the advancement of educational materials to support the evolving energy utilities industry. As the electrical power Smart Grid is being developed in all parts of the nation, the educational and professional development products from the UPDATE project have the potential to benefit both employers and technicians in the energy utility industry. Supporting the development of the Smart Grid contributes to enduring, reliable delivery of electrical power, which is vital to economic health and national security. Project outcomes include developing pathways both for new entrants into the energy utilities workforce and for incumbent workers in need of currency in Smart Grid technology.

Smart Grid technology is changing the methods and the infrastructure used for the delivery of power on the nation's electrical grid. The UPDATE project supports the establishment of a more highly skilled and adaptable energy utilities workforce. This is being accomplished by producing educational materials for utilities technician education that are enhanced with competencies for Smart Grid technology. Additionally, the UPDATE project is: 1. providing professional development opportunities for two-year college educators in the energy and utilities fields; 2. establishing outreach programs to inform middle and high school students and their teachers and counselors about careers as utilities technicians; and 3. developing standard credentials for Smart Grid technician education at the certificate and associate degree level. The UPDATE project team is working with experts from the Electrical Power Research Institute to validate the new curricular materials, identify core competencies related to Smart Grid technician education and explore industry recognized credentials for Smart Grid technicians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UPDATE project was designed with the goal of creating a more highly skilled and adaptable workforce by establishing a robust pathway for utilities students and incumbent workers in Northeast Wisconsin to meet industry workforce demand and establishing a replicable training model for other two-year colleges. To meet this goal, the project objectives were to: 1) Expand outreach to K12 students and instructors regarding technical career opportunities in utilities areas, 2) Infuse the utilities and energy curriculum with Smart Grid technologies and concepts, and 3) Deepen the credibility and broaden the availability of utilities training for technicians. The  disciplinary focus of the project was utilities technology education. Activities included: outreach to middle and high school students and their instructors, professional development to energy and utilities instructors at two-year colleges, curriculum and education materials development, and the development and enhancement of industry, business and academic partnerships.  

 Intellectual Merit. The energy industry is experiencing a “revolution” within utilities’ infrastructure: Smart Grid technologies are helping to change the power and energy world. Some industry experts believe that the Smart Grid is to the electric energy sector what the Internet was to the communication sector. While Department of Energy and National Science Foundation grants have helped jump-start Smart Grid training opportunities, most innovations in advanced technological education have been focused at the four-year level rather than at the technician level. The technician training opportunities that do exist have been somewhat isolated, and credentials for Smart Grid technician training are not as robust as credentials for other energy and utilities sectors. Through this project, NWTC leveraged resources and previous experience to develop effective recruitment strategies to jump-start interest in the sector and establish a robust pathway to skill-up current and future worker in Smart Grid technologies.

 Broader Impacts. The need for skilled energy and utilities technicians has never been greater as the workforce is aging and workers with a higher level of skills are needed immediately. A long-term goal for NWTC is to become a regional center for Smart Grid Technical Training; however, in order to become a recognized leader in this field, the College needed to develop a complete utilities training pipeline that feature Smart Grid competencies and ensures that the instruction will result in skilled workers for Wisconsin. Therefore, extensive outreach and education was provided to help K12 students and instructors better understand that the utilities sector relies on advanced technology and provides a good income. Smart Grid concepts were infused into the energy and utilities curriculum at NWTC. Program curriculum and recruitment strategies were shared with other two-year colleges interested in starting a program and/or revising curriculum at home institutions. Working with industry partners, the UPDATE project created a rubric for quality curriculum that can be used not only in Wisconsin, but by any institution that will be providing Smart Grid technician training.
